prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Considerations Governing the Protection of Intellectual Property

head.headtext: Means for Protecting Intellectual Property—Qualified monopoly (as in copyright)

para.paratext: The protection of copyright and patents is accomplished by state intervention.

In copyright, the state provides economic and moral rights to the creators of literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works. The policy behind this is to provide an incentive for the creation of artistic and literary works by recognizing and rewarding the effort involved in creating the work.

There is no copyright in an idea, but only in the manner in which the idea is expressed. Unlike patents, copyright does not require disclosure of the expression of the idea, and long-term protection is afforded to unpublished works. Although there is no requirement to register a work, it is more difficult to establish a right to copyright protection of a work which has not been registered.
Copyright law frequently operates to protect confidential business information through liberal interpretations of what constitutes “literary” and “artistic” works.[1]
R.G. Hammond, “The Origins of the Equitable Duty of Confidence” (1980), 8 Ang.-Am. L.R. 71.
